H0.text: Glaciers in the area melted as a result of India colliding with and becoming part of Asia according to continental drift theory.

H1.text: Large mountain ranges to form are caused by India’s collision with Asia, according to the theory of continental drift.

H2.text: Deep mid‑ocean trenches to develop are caused by India’s collision with and incorporation into Asia, as explained by the theory of continental drift.

H3.text: Deserts in the area became fertile as a result of India colliding with and becoming part of Asia, according to the theory of continental drift.

A4.text: The collision caused the lithospheric mantle of the Lhasa terrane to thicken and shorten, forming a barrier that later prevented the Indian lithosphere from fully subducting under Tibet and leading to further thickening of the Tibetan plateau.

A5.text: The rain shadowing of Himalayas are also believed to play an important part in the formation of Central Asian deserts, such as the Taklamakan and Gobi.
